sen.j: 小中村 清矩（こなかむら きよのり、文政4年12月30日 (旧暦)（1822年1月22日）- 明治28年（1895年）10月11日）は、国学者・歴史家。
sen.e: Kiyonori KONAKAMURA (January 22, 1822 - October 11, 1895) was a scholar of Japanese classical literature and historian.
Kiyonori KONAKAMURA (January 22, 1822 - October 11, 1895) was a scholar of Japanese classical literature and historian.
Kiyonori KONAKAMURA (January 22, 1822 - October 11, 1895) was a scholar of Japanese classical literature and historian.

sen.j: 姓は紀氏。
sen.e: His family name was from the Ki clan.
sen.cmt: 姓は紀氏→family name was from the Ki clanとしました。
sen.e: His family name was from the Ki clan.
His original surname was Ki, the lineage of Ki clan.
sen.cmt: ここでいう姓は本姓（源氏、平氏、その他）のことのようで、紀氏はその他に分類されるようです。Fromを削除

sen.j: 幼名は栄之助・金四郎・金右衛門・将曹と称した。
sen.e: His childhood names was Einosuke, Kinshiro, Kinemon, and Shoso (将曹).
sen.cmt: 将曹→正式な読み方が不明です：Shoso (将曹)としました。
sen.e: His childhood names was Einosuke, Kinshiro, Kinemon, and Shoso.
His childhood names was Einosuke, Kinshiro, Kinemon, and Shoso.

sen.j: 号は陽春廬（やすむろ）。
sen.e: His pseudonym was Yasumuro.
His pseudonym was Yasumuro.
His pseudonym was Yasumuro.

sen.j: 文政4年（1821年）年末、江戸麹町（現在の東京都千代田区）に生まれる。
sen.e: At the end of the year 1821, he was born in Koji-machi, Edo (present Chiyoda Ward, Tokyo Prefecture).
At the end of the year 1821, he was born in Koji-machi, Edo (present Chiyoda Ward, Tokyo Prefecture).
At the end of the year 1821, he was born in Koji-machi, Edo (present Chiyoda Ward, Tokyo Prefecture).

sen.j: 父は原田次郎八、母は美代。
sen.e: His father was Jirohachi HARADA, and his mother was Miyo.
His father was Jirohachi HARADA, and his mother was Miyo.
His father was Jirohachi HARADA, and his mother was Miyo.

sen.j: 父母に早世されたため、母の妹に養われ小中村家を継ぐ。
sen.e: As his parents died early, he was fostered by his smaller sister and took over the Konakamura family.
As his parents died early, he was fostered by his mother's younger sister and took over the Konakamura family.
sen.cmt: mother's younger sister に訂正しました。
sen.e: As his parents died early, he was fostered by his mother's younger sister and took over the Konakamura family.

sen.j: 小中村家の出自は石清水八幡宮の神職で、江戸に下って商業を営んでいた。
sen.e: The Konakamura family, whose origin was the family which produced Shinto priests at Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine, had left Kyoto to Edo to do commercial business.
The Konakamura family, whose origin was the family which produced Shinto priests at Iwashimizu Hachiman-gu Shrine, had left Kyoto to Edo to do commercial business.
sen.cmt: ハイフン補足しました。
sen.e: The Konakamura family, whose origin was the family which produced Shinto priests at Iwashimizu Hachiman-gu Shrine, had left Kyoto to Edo to do commercial business.

sen.j: 天保5年（1834年）、名を清矩に改めた。
sen.e: In 1834, he changed his name to Kiyonori.
In 1834, he changed his name to Kiyonori.
In 1834, he changed his name to Kiyonori.

sen.j: 養父の歿後家業を継ぐ一方、学問を堀越開山・置賜晰斎・西島蘭渓・中村六右衛門・亀田鶯谷・伊能穎則らより受ける。
sen.e: After his adoptive father's death, while he succeeded to the family business, he learned under Kaizan HORIKOSHI, Sekisai OKITAMA (置賜晰斎), Rankei NISHIJIMA, Rokuuemon NAKAMURA, Okoku KAMEDA, Hidenori INO, and others.
sen.cmt: 置賜晰斎→正式な読み方が不明です：Sekisai OKITAMA (置賜晰斎)としました。
sen.e: After his adoptive father's death, while he succeeded to the family business, he learned under Kaizan HORIKOSHI, Sekisai OKITAMA (置賜晰斎), Rankei NISHIJIMA, Rokuuemon NAKAMURA, Okoku KAMEDA, Hidenori INO, and others.
sen.cmt: 置賜晰斎→正式な読み方が不明です
sen.e: After his adoptive father's death, while he succeeded to the family business, he learned under Kaizan HORIKOSHI, Sekisai OKITAMA (置賜晰斎), Rankei NISHIJIMA, Rokuuemon NAKAMURA, Okoku KAMEDA, Hidenori INO, and others.

sen.j: 嘉永5年（1852年）、家業を次子文次郎に譲って学業に専念した。
sen.e: In 1852, he handed over the family business to the second son, Bunjiro, and concentrated in academic learning.
sen.cmt: 次子文次郎→the second son, Bunjiroとしましたが、清矩の次男を指すのか、小中村家(養家）の次男を指すのか不明。
sen.e: In 1852, he handed over the family business to the second son, Bunjiro, and concentrated in academic learning.
In 1852, he handed over the family business to the second son, Bunjiro, and concentrated in academic learning.

sen.j: 安政2年（1855年）、本居内遠に入門。
sen.e: In 1855, he became a discipline of Uchitoo MOTOORI.
In 1855, he became a discipline of Uchitoo MOTOORI.
In 1855, he became a discipline of Uchitoo MOTOORI.

sen.j: 安政4年（1857年）、和歌山藩古学館教授となり、文久2年（1862年）、江戸幕府和学講談所講師となった。
sen.e: In 1857, he became a professor at Kogakukan (古学館) academy of ancient learning) of Wakayama Domain, and in 1862 he became a lecturer at Wagaku-kodansho (institute of national learning) of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: 和歌山藩古学館→定訳不明・正式な読み方が不明です：Kogakukan (古学館) （academy of ancient learning) of Wakayama Domainとしました。 江戸幕府和学講談所→定訳不明：Wagaku-kodansho (institute of national learning) of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)としました。
sen.e: In 1857, he became a professor at Kogakukan academy of ancient learning) of Wakayama Domain, and in 1862 he became a lecturer at Wagaku-kodansho (institute of national learning) of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

In 1857, he became a professor at Kogakukan academy of ancient learning) of Wakayama Domain, and in 1862 he became a lecturer at Wagaku-kodansho (institute of national learning) of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 明治2年（1869年）、太政官に出仕し、大学中助教に就任。
sen.e: In 1869, he served the government as Dajokan (Great Council of State) and also took the post of Daigaku Chujokyo (大学中助教) (middle assistant professor of higher education).
sen.cmt: 大学中助教→定訳不明・正式な読み方が不明です： Daigaku Chujokyo (大学中助教) (middle assistant professor of higher education)としました。
sen.e: In 1869, he served the government as Dajokan (Great Council of State) and also took the post of Daigaku Chujokyo (middle assistant professor of higher education).
sen.cmt: 漢字表記を削除しました。
sen.e: In 1869, he served the government as Dajokan (Great Council of State) and also took the post of Daigaku Chujokyo (middle assistant professor of higher education).

sen.j: 太政官制度の取調にあたった。
sen.e: He was engaged in the investigation of Dajokan System.
He was engaged in the investigation of Dajokan System.
He was engaged in the investigation of Dajokan System.

sen.j: 神祇官神祇権大史・神祇大史・神祇大録・教部省教部大録を経て、明治11年（1878年）、東京大学講師と、修史館御用掛になる。
sen.e: After holding the position of Jingikan Jingigon no taishi, Jingidaishi, Jingidairoku, and Kyobusho (Ministry of Religion) Kyobudairoku, in 1878 he became a lecturer at The University of Tokyo and Goyogakari (a general affaires official of the Imperial Household) at Shushikan (a national institute established to compile the official Japanese history).
sen.cmt: 修史館御用掛→定訳不明：Goyogakari (a general affaires official of the Imperial Household) at Shushikan (a national institute established to compile the official Japanese history）としました。
sen.e: After holding the position of Jingikan Jingigon no taishi, Jingidaishi, Jingidairoku, and Kyobusho (Ministry of Religion) Kyobudairoku, in 1878 he became a lecturer at the University of Tokyo and Goyogakari (a general affaires official of the Imperial Household) at Shushikan (a national institute established to compile the official Japanese history).

After holding the position of Jingikan Jingigon no taishi, Jingidaishi, Jingidairoku, and Kyobusho (Ministry of Religion) Kyobudairoku, in 1878 he became a lecturer at the University of Tokyo and Goyogakari (a general affaires official of the Imperial Household) at Shushikan (a national institute established to compile the official Japanese history).

sen.j: 翌明治12年、『古事類苑』編纂に従事し、明治15年（1882年）、東京大学教授・東京学士院会員となり、明治19年、東京大学法科兼文科大学教授に就任、併せて『古事類苑』編纂委員長となった。
sen.e: In 1879 he was engaged in the compilation of "Kojiruien" (an encyclopedia of ancient literatures), in 1882 he became a professor at The Tokyo University as well as a member of the Tokyo gakushiin (Tokyo Academy), and in addition, he was appointed to be the chairperson of the editorial committee of "Kojiruien."
sen.cmt: 『古事類苑』→定訳不明："Kojiruien" (an encyclopedia of ancient literatures) としました。
sen.e: In 1879 he was engaged in the compilation of "Kojiruien" (an encyclopedia of ancient literatures), in 1882 he became a professor at the Tokyo University as well as a member of the Tokyo gakushiin (Tokyo Academy), and in addition, he was appointed to be the chairperson of the editorial committee of "Kojiruien."

In 1879 he was engaged in the compilation of "Kojiruien" (an encyclopedia of ancient literatures), in 1882 he became a professor at the Tokyo University as well as a member of the Tokyo gakushiin (Tokyo Academy), and in addition, he was appointed to be the chairperson of the editorial committee of "Kojiruien."

sen.j: 明治21年（1888年）、博士 (文学)の学位を取得し、帝室制度取調掛に任命され、明治23年（1890年）、貴族院 (日本)議員に勅選され、明治26年（1893年）、法典調査会査定委員となった。
sen.e: In 1888 he received doctorate in literature, and he was appointed as Torishirabegakari (a researcher) of the department of the Imperial Household system), in 1890 he was selected as a member of the House of Peers by the Imperial command, and in 1893 he became a member of the evaluation subcommittee of the National Code research committee.
sen.cmt: 帝室制度取調掛→定訳不明：Torishirabegakari (a researcher) of the department of the Imperial Household system)としました。 査定委員→定訳不明：a member of the evaluation subcommitteeとしました。 法典調査会 →定訳不明：the National Code research committeeとしました。
sen.e: In 1888 he received doctorate in literature, and he was appointed as Torishirabegakari (a researcher) of the department of the Imperial Household system, in 1890 he was selected as a member of the House of Peers by the Imperial command, and in 1893 he became a member of the evaluation subcommittee of the National Code research committee.

In 1888 he received doctorate in literature, and he was appointed as Torishirabegakari (a researcher) of the department of the Imperial Household system, in 1890 he was selected as a member of the House of Peers by the Imperial command, and in 1893 he became a member of the evaluation subcommittee of the National Code research committee.

sen.j: 明治27年（1895年）、75歳で死去。
sen.e: He died in 1895 at the age of 75.
He died in 1895 at the age of 75.
He died in 1895 at the age of 75.

sen.j: 正五位に叙された。
sen.e: After his death, he was raised to Shogoi (Senior Fifth Rank)
After his death, he was raised to Shogoi (Senior Fifth Rank)
After his death, he was raised to Shogoi (Senior Fifth Rank)

sen.j: 墓は東京谷中の天王寺墓地。
sen.e: His grave is found at Tennoji Cemetery in Yanaka, Tokyo.
His grave is found at Tennoji Cemetery in Yanaka, Tokyo.
His grave is found at Tennoji Cemetery in Yanaka, Tokyo.

sen.j: 国文学者池辺義象の養父（のち池辺に復する）。
sen.e: He was the adoptive father of the scholar of Japanese literature, Yoshikata IKEBE (he later recovered his original surname 'Ikebe').
sen.cmt: のち池辺に復する→he later recovered his original surname 'Ikebe'としました。
sen.e: He was the adoptive father of the scholar of Japanese literature, Yoshikata IKEBE (he later recovered his original surname 'Ikebe').
He was the adoptive father of the scholar of Japanese literature, Yoshikata IKEBE (he later recovered his original surname 'Ikebe').
